holidays.name: National Hugging Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to encouraging people to hug more often to promote happiness and reduce stress.
holidays.origin: Created by Kevin Zaborney in 1986, who believed that people didn’t hug enough and that hugs were a powerful way to show caring and affection.
holidays.funFact: Research shows that hugging releases oxytocin, the 'love hormone,' which helps reduce anxiety and lower blood pressure.

holidays.name: Squirrel Appreciation Day
holidays.description: A quirky day to celebrate the mischievous and adorable squirrels that frequent parks and backyards worldwide.
holidays.origin: Founded in 2001 by Christy Hargrove of Asheville, North Carolina, who wanted to bring attention to squirrels beyond their reputation as pesky rodents.
holidays.funFact: Squirrels plant thousands of new trees annually by forgetting where they stash their nuts!

holidays.name: National Granola Bar Day
holidays.description: A tasty tribute to the popular snack that combines health, convenience, and yum in a handy bar.
holidays.origin: Originating as a promotional day by granola bar companies, it celebrates the snack’s energy-boosting qualities and versatility.
holidays.funFact: Granola bars were first marketed in the early 1900s as a health food for outdoor adventurers and athletes.

holidays.name: Be Bald and Be Free Day
holidays.description: A celebration of baldness and the freedom to embrace your natural look without societal pressures.
holidays.origin: Started by a group of people who wanted to challenge beauty norms and encourage confidence in baldness, regardless of gender.
holidays.funFact: Going bald can increase tactile sensitivity on the scalp — but far fewer hats are needed!
